title: Spear Phishing
content: Unlike regular phishing, spear phishing targets specific individuals using personal info — like your role, projects, or coworkers. Example: 'Hey Lisa, can you review this finance report before the meeting?' It looks personal but contains a malicious link.

title: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
content: Attackers impersonate a company executive or vendor to request urgent wire transfers or data. Example: An email from 'CEO@company.co' asking finance to send $10,000 immediately — but it’s a fake domain (CEO@company.co vs CEO@company.com).

title: Credential Harvesting
content: Fake login pages mimic real sites like Google or Office 365 to steal your credentials. Always double-check the domain (google.com vs g00gle-login.net). Enable MFA to block login attempts even if your password leaks.

title: Malicious Attachments
content: Office files or PDFs can carry hidden code (macros) that install malware. Example: 'Updated project.xlsx' sent by 'HR@company-career.net'. Always verify attachments before opening, even if they look professional.

title: Social Engineering Tricks
content: Phishers exploit emotions — urgency, fear, or curiosity. Example: 'You’ve won a gift card!' or 'Your account will be closed today!' The goal is to make you click fast without thinking.

title: Defense-in-Depth
content: Combine multiple defenses: MFA, password managers, employee training, patching, and email filtering. Cybersecurity isn’t one tool — it’s a habit. Stay alert and question anything that feels 'off'.
